{"docs":[{"title":"The All-embracing Net of Views","summary":"The Buddha explains virtue through abstention in many ways, and outlines wrong livelihood as fortune telling, predicting the future, and other mystical activities for brahmins and recluses. He then goes on to outline wrong views, including eternalism, annihilationism, immortality, etc as well as wrong views of nibbana as mere sense pleasures or jhana. Fiinally, he ends the discourse by comparing these views to a net, which entraps their adherents. Only by understanding origin & passing of 6 bases of contact, satisfaction & unsatisfactoriness, and their escape can they transcend the net of views.","tags":["(S) net of views","annihilationism","eternalism","view (wrong)","virtue","livelihood (wrong)"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/dn1"],"_id":"DN:1","_rev":"1-5563ca8c4e9971c637e40a280b459907"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:10","_rev":"1-51b53c601417ef029f0e99ba3086cca8"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:11","_rev":"1-e7c1b226564ee18017000e9ba661e41f"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:12","_rev":"1-b6a0108c4a151fef90102c5e972f4b66"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:13","_rev":"1-d53208ca55f31672649448dba9f47599"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:14","_rev":"1-e77adb8a75a8c1ffc2eb0609e1a4adb6"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:15","_rev":"1-379e3e2260f0a312a117cb8feed91a8c"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:16","_rev":"1-a332f23c353d1abcbd605c10920aaa95"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:17","_rev":"1-669294bd7814a5da2936d62a8cd77128"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:18","_rev":"1-baa95cb7d21e99890d05092eeead9ffd"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:19","_rev":"1-a41d7ddc39f4d82dad17967cd661cc50"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:2","_rev":"1-e5d722d2b078c94de47e0a7094c149f9"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:20","_rev":"1-154715ff2389cb43c2c6bfe82fe2510e"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:21","_rev":"1-61482f8d86b0c0829042721ca0c2970a"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:22","_rev":"1-fe49623c3e752f29629667f61e9942af"},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"DN:23","_rev": {"seq":8294}
{"docs":[{"title":"The Lesser Discourse on Emptiness","summary":"The Buddha tells Ananda how he abides in emptiness. This is done by successively understanding the perception of what is not there and the perception of what is and how the disturbances associated with each may or may not be present depending on what the perception is. As he perceives something, he notes that the previous perception is absent, along with all the others, \"not attending\" to them.  His flow of perceptions start with the village, people, forest, earth, base of infinite space, base of infinite consciousness, base of nothingness, base of neither perception nor non-perception, signless concentration of the mind, and finally knowing the disturbance of the six sense bases \"conditioned by life.\"","tags":["emptiness","perception","immaterial states","nibbana"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/mn/mn.121.than.html"],"_id":"MN:121","_rev":"10-9db5f21403eb29074082c1f2ad41788c","_revisions":{"start":10,"ids":["9db5f21403eb29074082c1f2ad41788c","9d2f44fe4adfe2a78b6c392d0a6d6d6b","27d53c706b9bda726429949b7dafd515","380d400a89f66b15e056fda05e5d36da","6ae9cc6428e5d1f4cd4a81fdaf05df86","41c43afb3bb83b09042e2132b4e7f1ca","38e71d0509baade1f1df26da7dd2c0aa","6ec92a305884a63d878d26a56a31690d","494d1517cce9b0249f2bbc4911b9e7d7","1951cdf9b11d296e26290f149163df52"]}},{"title":"The Shorter Exposition of Action","summary":"Subha asks the Buddha what the cause of certain characteristics is, such as short lived/long lived, sickly/healthy, ugly/beautiful, uninfluential/influential, poor/wealthy, low-born/high-born, stupid/wise. The Buddha replies that it is action that makes this distinction.  He goes on to describe how each comes to be, in a format that starts with the negative and only happens if one is reborn back into the human realm if not a realm of deprivation.\n\nIt is killing & violence which can land one to a realm of deprivation, or to a very short life in the human world if not born into the deprivation state. The opposite happens if one is non-violent (heavenly realms or a long human life).  If one is prone to hitting/striking others they can land in a hell realm, or be reborn as an ugly human.  They'll be reborn in to a \"happy destination\", or as a healthy human if they are gentle, compassionate, and kind.  For someone who is easily angered and irritable, they can be reborn as an ugly person, beautiful otherwise if not born into a hell realm.  For someone who is envious/resentful, it's either a state of deprivation or an uninfluential human.  One who is not generous, if reborn as a human, will be poor. One who is obstinant & arrogant, if reborn a human, will be \"low-born\" or not honored and venerated.  One who does not seek advice on living a wholesome life will be reborn stupid or unwise, unless born into a realm of deprivation.","tags":["rebirth","kamma","wealth","beauty","ugliness","generosity","honor","wholesomeness","violence","killing","arrogance","fortunate rebirth"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/mn135"],"_id":"MN:135","_rev":"8-15a28a63a0ad44f54a9ceea711f1603a","_revisions":{"start":8,"ids":["15a28a63a0ad44f54a9ceea711f1603a","5f9b105bb023be37ae5fc4e9cddb4f82","9cebc3cf3ce5e3964534a84f901c8c25","2f36c25d7eec2fbb6925db23b94802e9","8001876ed501686f6bdc30b94e172e6f","d44656ebb7ee61208da710535b59b039","abfd985b17faf3c8b7c1f607ece1fbe8","dedd3291acf7abd5c9828ab461b6575f"]}},{"title":"The Removal of Distracting Thoughts","summary":"The budda","tags":["abandonment","distractions","thought","effort"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/mn20"],"_id":"MN:20","_rev":"7-5018fed25f69e6348720a86615d27e68","_revisions":{"start":7,"ids":["5018fed25f69e6348720a86615d27e68","2f283035bef247e7d3367cb8a1c67380","ef30fad8eb0d086be1b9cbd6ff942faf","0e5edeca118d83d9190fef2437ac74ae","120c86b2346335ebee1005b9bfa41c2f","d0330f7cd6ba7168caa2c1fa3b6cb9c8","b22842a5626e06018cb4fb1dd67117b9"]}}]}

{"docs":[{"title":"Mūlapariyāya Sutta - The Root of All Things","summary":"The Buddha explains the difference between an uninstructed person, a disciple of higher training, an an arahat, and the tathagata in relation to how they view themselves as a part of the world through topics such as the four elements (eg arahant vies them as not self, worldling conceives elements as himself, himself in them, apart from them, or as 'mine'). At the end, he tells us that \"delight is the root of suffering\" and that it is the relinquishment of craving which has liberated him.","tags":["arahat","delight","conceive","four elements"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/mn1"],"_id":"MN:1","_rev":"35-77cf19f3486cb51bd103742d7326def3","_revisions":{"start":35,"ids":["77cf19f3486cb51bd103742d7326def3","bce4fd8f67bf65da5fd16dfa8f317aea","e64fb7ad00b38fa2921294d0e43087e0","8557826737dd418cc6f779a07b38cdbb","aedc6b554fa85817ea30fe66f12c6bf5","a1f849fe655ccb4bff1bcce1da480fd2","2428faa566341b083afdeead6e93381c","7357367c5ea65c9144c856a8fd35f433","03d951ab7399ccbc404de5b0843e3d5f","e99e981c61fbf5adec47524952eb7186","8aad75ed468a0e9fa5d788f17aff1843","680dfddfe2f4187badd01f8e4d18ae8d","ad6c8376ce27908cae8ecc1196690f56","da8c7fd12283ae0189de0c15c4086df9","55d131e0fae31423a86a388c0ee236c4","323d751495ffe57bb3262440aebe6460","4f03fb12414f14e56a56d7a622b00f82","7e544008332a31f714297dcf2e2893bc","499f41e35b3e81137d0c3eb8b25cda1e","61311b0d75229f25c834f0069e042dc2","58e34e8565ee5a94e3efb878029da9af","270e8aac5000b8d937c8545f5cd71984","20c115744a119da4ee744c764d993be8","75f616150dfe508ee2a96d5c17fcf815","c0b672e7de157dbb62d6a9f020394c66","eea9d5ee7d7831e466c8b44770eb04bb","b1010c0aa4dac44767d56cb37c5fcc58","9f6d63314e3e0f3405c91bc7a80e44f8","51cf41e9505253d6c15139012ca998f3","e9c13dce08f8883147c3463d84265b3c","898018a9fe0de8a7a05c00eb87c9e91e","bbe2ae6386b3f6f6df198f623b3169f1","05d256cce5faaf0ae1385aa465f3ddb0","68d8aeb155681e1512974842108b03b6","eb30a01cefe67db7471f1bef5bad5c46"]}},{"title":"Sabbāsava Sutta - All the Taints","summary":"The buddha describes 7 ways of abandoning taints. The 7 ways are by seeing (attending wisely to sensual desire, being, and ignorance), by restraining (the 6 sense bases), by using (the requisites for their intended basic purpose), by enduring (transient stressors like pains & flies), by avoiding (dangerous animals, vegetation, and bad friends), by removing (not tolerating ill will, sensual desire, unwholesome states etc), and by developing (develop the 7 enlightenment factors).\n\nThis sutta also explains anatta as not-self rather than no-self, as that would be engaging in a \"thicket of views\"","tags":["taints (abandoning)","attention","restraint","sense bases","requisites","enlightenment factors (seven)","anatta","view (right)","view (wrong)","thicket of views"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/mn2"],"_id":"MN:2","_rev":"6-721c43a83b78f42e5613f394fb7f8126","_revisions":{"start":6,"ids":["721c43a83b78f42e5613f394fb7f8126","5919ff3bb26bff39799451471a440d07","05414b0214d09e3a64a9f08d5583bea5","25edbff2042fe328bc9956dd4503add9","d28d911478d33a891f4411759140fc40","9366323a444f7dc13fffc45c7b8c04fd"]}},{"title":"Anangaṇa Sutta - Without Blemishes","summary":"Sariputta addresses the bhikkhus by saying there are four kinds of people found in the world.\n\n1) A person w/ a blemish does not understand that he has a blemish in himself\n2) A person w/ a blemish understands that he has a blemish\n3) A person w/out a blemish does not understand thus\n4) A person w/out a blemish understands thus\n\nThe inferior of these four types are 1 and 3 because they do not understand rightly, leading them to not make an effort to remove it and will die with lust hate and delusion.  He is like a bronze dish that has dirt and stains which multiply as time goes one due to carelessness. A person who recognizes his blemishes are expected to make an effort to abandon it and die without greed, hatred, and delusion like a bronze plate that is continuously cared for.\nA person without a blemish who does not understand will be careless, and is expected to give attention to the \"sign of the beautiful\", arousing lust and eventually dying with the three poisons. He is like a clean bronze plate that is left uncared for in a dusty corner.  But a person with right understanding that no blemish is present is expected to not give attention to the sign of the beautiful, meaning lust will not infect his mind, dying without the 3 poisons like a bronze plate that is continuously cleaned taken care of.\nIt is explained that blemish refers to \"spheres of evil unwholesome wishes\". \nSuppose a bhikkhu wishes that, if he commits an offense, that that either the bhikkhus do not know of it, that they admonish him in private, or that an equal admonishes him. But if the opposite comes true, and he is angry and bitter, those qualities are blemishes.  If he wishes that \na teacher teaches the Dhamma by asking questions about him [presumable good aspects] rather than another], \nthat the bhikkhus put him ahead in the alms round line, \nthat he wishes for the best water or food or seating, \nthat he might give the blessing after the meal, \nthat he may get to teach the fourfold assembly not some other bhikkhu, \nthat the fourfold assembly honors, reveres, respects and venerates him,\nthat he might be the one to get a superior robe or alms or medicinal requisites.\nIf the opposite comes true and he has anger or bitterness, then that anger and bitterness are called blemishes.\n\nIf these are not abandoned by a monk who even is a forest dweller, frequents remote abodes, eats almsfood, rag-wearer, even then he will not get respect from fellows of the holy life.  He is like a bronze plate filled with a carcass and covered with a lid.\n\nYet if these evil spheres are abandoned and he is a village dweller, accepts invitations, wears robes given to him by householders, his companions in the holy life will respect and revere him. He would be like a bronze plate with rice, sauces and delicious dishes, covered with a lid.\n\nMahamogallana then recounts a simile of Ajivaka Panduputta who wishes a cartwright to plane a bend/twist/fault out of an outer rim of a wooden wheel. Mogallana compares Sariputta to the Ajivaka in terms of straightening people who have bad qualities (such as going forth for the purpose of seeking livelihood instead of out of faith, fraudulence, deceit, haughty, hollow, vain, etc).","tags":["faith","3 poisons","going forth","anger","bitterness","lust","blemish","sphere of evil wishes","respect"],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"MN:5","_rev":"12-2f8207c790e00d878a894fd28d20176a","_revisions":{"start":12,"ids":["2f8207c790e00d878a894fd28d20176a","43c8efd0a52b1dea5d7bb601e4591e34","7322fb395d3a58b82f2026070f2f5e4b","2fafa5d0db5bb4a5b562eb36844a6847","91a6feb25f3804395004ac5f89a96c6d","aa5bc3dbac67fc9999126b75541b7475","f310fa901b3f28a2a110416030ffa1ef","c8ea6f4210809ef1973d752d753ae833","a8b691b02e739a6dd3294f29964760d1","b68421daee5b7cdf884687c1428846d0","a9e4d0bdebe0dba33c83ac361d9a9e7e","fd9f64500abf9f2a635b023f64762b3a"]}},{"title":"Ākankheyya Sutta - If a Bhikkhu Should Wish","summary":"This sutta is all about virtue, possessing the Patimokkha, perfection of conduct, and seeing fear in the slightest misconduct. \nIf a bhikkhu should wish any of the following, \"let him fulfill the precepts, devote himself to serenity of mind, not neglect meditation, posess insight, and dwell in empty huts\":\n- wanting to be dear and agreeable to other holy people\n- may i obtain robes, alms, a resting place, and medicinal requisites\n- may the services of those who gave the above requisites bring them great benefit (?)\n- may my relatives who have passed away and died remember me with confidence in their minds (the dead remember?)\n- may i conquer discontent\n- may i conquer fear and dread\n- may i obtain at will the 4 jhanas\n- may i contact the body and abide in those liberations that are peacefua and immaterial, transcending forms (immaterial states according to BB)\n- may i become a stream enterer\n- ... a once returner\n- ... a non-returner\n- may i wield supernormal powers such as \"becoming many\" & coming back to one, appear & vanish, go through solids, walk on water, travel in space cross legged, touch & stroke the moon & sun, \"wield bodily mastery\"\n- may i hear divine & human sounds near & far with the divine ear element\n- may i understand the minds of other beings (a mind affected or unaffected by lust, hate, delusion,a contracted/uncontracted, distracted, (un)exalted, (un)surpassed, (un)concentrated, (un)liberated\n- may i recollect my past lives\n- may i see beings pass away and reappearing inferior/superior, fair/ugly, fortunate/unfortunate, in accordance with their actions with the divine eye\n- may i attain nibbana","tags":["virtue","patimokkha","misconduct","fear","desire","jhana","immaterial states","enlightenment","supernatural powers","kamma","divine eye","divine ear"],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"MN:6","_rev":"6-b558786f93c9b4018ed116bbadf89268","_revisions":{"start":6,"ids":["b558786f93c9b4018ed116bbadf89268","357e5f679eec83f1ad0420b32e401838","8462d88e5436030f5ff98182c4e38518","be3d34a784b049486a0fcf5719fd2cf5","f1b496b2dd0d640c1b84d89fd2db7678","df462891a8e5a0b254c3aee1a969751d"]}}]}

{"docs":[{"title":"Bhayabherava Sutta - Fear and Dread","summary":"The brahmin Janussoni hypothesizes that, for one without concentration, \"one would think the jungles must rob a bhikkhu of his mind\" and the Buddha agrees.  However, the Buddha also says that he found great solace in dwelling in the forest since he is purified in bodily, verbal, mental, & livelihood conduct since those with unpurified conduct evoke \"unwholesome fear and dread\".  The unpurified states he mentions are:\ncovetousness \nill will\nsloth & torpor\nrestlessness and \"unpeaceful in mind\"\nuncertainty and doubting\nself-praise and disparagement of others\ngiving to alarm and terror\ndesirous of gain, honor, renown\nlazy\nunconcentrated\nHis solace with the forest comes from the fact that he is the opposite of all these things. Before, when he did have fear and dread, he explains that he would not change his position at all until he subdued those feelings.  He then asserts his welfare for the world along with his correct perceptions.  Then recounts his going through the 4 jhanas, eventually turning toward recollecting his past lives.  \n\nThat was his first watch of the night of his awakening. His second was that of the passing away and reappearance of beings according to their actions (kamma). His third knowledge on the third watch is the penetration of the 4 noble truths, and the knowledge \"it is liberated\", having no more sensual desire.\n\nThere are 2 striking things about the sections on the watches.  1 is that the phrase \"directly knew as it actually is\" is used as a testimony for non-intellectualism. The other is the phrase \"as happens in one who abides diligent, ardent, and resolute\" as though these 3 things can/will happen to a noble disciple.","tags":["jhana","three watches","four noble truths","buddha's enlightenment","reincarnation","divine eye","enlightenment","direct knowledge"],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"MN:4","_rev":"9-16ae7d82ee09f6f274c723563f18148c","_revisions":{"start":9,"ids":["16ae7d82ee09f6f274c723563f18148c","8e7831dd1cbf01b9788574b65df6505e","b570bddeb18778ae97d7851b31b81306","33f488de8d4e3f6078bef7ef5786d2e6","a29db803e81ec11167044bc5a6cba0ea","bd0ef075e875656cc264a61c436a72b2","a5aa155eb8f042438db3b96c9c594a76","470c158c98aeadcaab23be6300176f00","501df8b4f30dd724d3fae5e3fe040775"]}},{"title":"Vatthūpama Sutta - The Simile of the Cloth","summary":"The mind is like a cloth.  When dyed, if the cloth is defiled and stained the resulting dye job would look poor and impure, whereas a \"pure and bright\" cloth would look good and pure when dyed a certain color.  The defiled mind will lead to a unhappy destination while an undefiled mind can expect a happy destination.  The imperfections that defile the mind are:\n- covetousness & unrighteous greed\n- Ill will, anger, resentment, contempt, insolence, envy, avarice, deciet, fraud, obstinancy, rivalry, conceit, arrogance, vanity, negligence.\n\nKnowing these imperfections, a bhikkhu abandons them. Once he has abandoned them (presumably for good?) he acquires unwavering confidence in the Budda as one who is fully enlightened, perfect in true knowledge & conduct, sublime, teacher of gods and humans, etc. He also aquires unwavering confidence in the Dhamma, that it is well proclaimed, visible in the here & now, immediately effective, etc. Also with the sangha, as practicing the good way, the proper way (the 4 pairs of persons/8 types of individuals) and are worthy of gifts and reverence and are fields of unsurpassed merit.\n\nAnd when he has abandoned them in part, he considers thus himself as having unwavering confidence in the buddha, dhamma, & sangha, gains inspiration in the meaning, inspiration in the Dhamma, and gains gladness in the dhamma. This gladness produces pīti -> bodily tranquility -> pleasure -> concentrated mind.\n\nFor a bhikkhu of such virtue & state of concentration, the choicest foods won't be an obstacle for him, like a stained cloth that has become pure using clear water or gold purified by a furnace.  He abides with mettā, karunā, muditā, upekkhā everywhere, without hostility or ill will. He understands (according to the commentaries) there is suffering, origin of suffering, truth of the path, and cessation (end commentary). \n\nWhen he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, the taint of being, and taint of ignorance, coming with the knowledge that it is liberated, and is called one \"bathed with the inner bathing\".\n\nThen the brahmin Sundarika Bhāradvāja asked if the Buddha goes to the Bāhukā river to bathe & gain liberation, merit and wash away evil actions. The Buddha responds in stanzas, saying you can not purify dark deeds with rivers(?).  It is one who is pure in heart that perfects virtue. Instead of bathing in water, he advises that he should bathe in virtue as a refuge for all beings, not speaking lies, nor harming beings, nor stealing, having faith and free from avarice.\n\nBhāradvāja then delights in this and asks to ordain, becoming an arahant \"not long after\" and dwelling alone, withdrawn, diligent, ardent, resolute.","tags":["bhrama viharas","concentration","jhāna","pīti","tranquility","mettā","karunā","muditā","upekkhā","arahant","nibbāna","four pairs of persons","defilements","cloth","ill will","anger","obstinancy","vanity","confidence"],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"MN:7","_rev":"16-837101c6281c15cb253316f35815d519","_revisions":{"start":16,"ids":["837101c6281c15cb253316f35815d519","198b2bd956b7bade62501d830e2f9d1a","a75c96bc07f1c34be41100dd2cb0521e","f5aa2ea500e2b121a2d46feb8821490a","fc53c509925a603d5632fd73e2c6e058","ef984795249234d511e089c07d98ba14","16230a2f6b1eb6de891bea2a1f151ef8","d9a5fa608a8ea0c5649e45f9d2a49072","22d080ded8c8f0b5ee35fa71e2e3edae","197deb401039b0de6cae631f8429a0bd","dd09f0f7ccb6645ef9cf4acba1713b85","81dd122c1da4fc3362092b95a6bd8dcd","33be788db8bae3c6087d609cc6c48039","683d750ad3420768adfefceb59f606b2","73b3d40c27c566f3378e049f1fa997bb","cf37161b8fed236b6d9c1e1f8b10895d"]}}]}

{"docs":[{"title":"Sallekha Sutta - Effacement","summary":"Mahā Cuna asks the buddha how views on self are eradicated.  The buddha replies that, viewing the \"object in relation to which those views arise\" as not mine, this i am not, this is not my self will bring about the abandoning and relinquishing of those views.  He then lists the 4 jhānas and immaterial states, proclaiming them to be 'pleasant abidings here and now' and not effacement. \n\nEffacement then, is a practice which incorporates many different things such as not being cruel, killing, stealing, sexual activities, lying, speaking maliciously, speaking harshly, etc. despite the fact others may do these things. There are 44 aspects in all here, encompassing the precepts, right speech, the eightfold path, 5 hinderances, and other wholesome qualities.  The mind should be inclined to the wholesome aspects of this list. Then, we have the wholesome qualities by which to avoid engaging with, to lead upwards, to extinguish the unwholesome qualities in the list. Perhaps this can mean that using the negation as a hard concept or mediation object can have great fruit.\n\nIn the section on extinguishing, a simile is given where one can not pull another out of the mud if one is also in the mud, but can if he is not. Similarly, an untamed, undisciplined person with defilements unextinguished can not tame another, discipline another, or help extinguish another's defilements.","tags":["effacement","abandoning","views","jhāna","immaterial states","relinquishment","meditation","eightfold path","cruelty","avarice","obstinancy"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/mn8"],"_id":"MN:8","_rev":"14-1d3f44905e42fd18da9beb65c7aed7eb","_revisions":{"start":14,"ids":["1d3f44905e42fd18da9beb65c7aed7eb","4186d2b55298fe6b70c9b5126c46162b","21de0fb9ebc6418f6be0d455613a8489","639ac65137771ba43a822dfc2ee10f00","8ddcf254da8e1540afe592b323afefb3","880aeb3f740f63c52cc92421a90a18df","9343b90a33809cfddaee1b909b80b3dd","def90f894799c1f17bc588388e59c10c","d5362166866d5cf0c02b439c38469360","ce6fee4ac83d062348c94514d719a5cc","fa53a3139fcc6ca22d95e285afb3f8d8","4206fd8e35b1e38d4e7feaaf720ef3ba","d77a05fe3da20a5f0f4863c2ab18757f","f92050ecb4d8f7e7949289034b30409f"]}},{"title":"Discourse on Ghaṭīkāra","summary":"The Buddha recollects a past life to Ānanda where he was a brahman, Jotipāla, with a potter friend.  The potter, Ghaṭīkāra, always tried getting the brahman to see the Lord Kassapa, but it took many many tries and a good hair-pulling before he conceded. Once he met him, however, he decided to go forth while Jotipāla stayed as a householder to take care of his parents. \n\nKing Kikī then met with Kassapa, and upon hearing his wise words offered him shelter for the rains retreat.  Kassapa declined, as it was already provided by Ghatīkāra. Though Kikī asked many times, Kassapa always declined, praising the potter with virtuous anecdotes of his & his parents' generosity.  Eventually the king decided to send 500 cartloads of rice and curry to the potter for his actions.  It is only at the very end does Gotama Buddha reveal he was Jotipāla in this story.","tags":["dāna","kassapa buddha","smiling","buddha's past life","early jataka"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/mn81"],"_id":"MN:81","_rev":"18-1b0b9d6f61c9cd7368b0a52e1d07fa3f","_revisions":{"start":18,"ids":["1b0b9d6f61c9cd7368b0a52e1d07fa3f","d534c13f93460daf1b6716788a26e3f3","aa801259be498253e7ca20ee0012f0b4","c6fcd85c13f495ad1eefd5d9d1b483b1","e0f7a2c2a24c48720a32f982856ff5de","d3377db4494b62fe5be2f6c8ddb0b13f","a70ddc6d1ce6a7a90615ac6de23122dd","0fa0b8c02bb2efb9c94cb97805ebc959","6ca3d0cc7aa5456984f1b88d058919e6","658ef489fa3ebdbb988104e22aadf52e","5791d05c61203fa079c6feb073d629fc","0b2068ab336f09ef74f05b3838857add","fdb07b19820243602958d382ea75aa0d","7babeecff4592c2f3e4ae9f352b2f259","a1799d28ed9f38bf22d4e875e6a9908f","f2eea02de9710ff00ffe06b339119447","52d5cf31c4efe6a7cebe605b446b3aca","9c5f8eb92c267b6fe5f00dd90ed6232e"]}},{"title":"","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/mn9"],"_id":"MN:9","_rev":"2-3de3bad1ead45942bd0197adb0c667b5","_revisions":{"start":2,"ids":["3de3bad1ead45942bd0197adb0c667b5","626466eeb3a8e9dcbbbe775c47243e4d"]}},{"title":"Crossing the flood","summary":"A beautiful devatā visits the Buddha & asks him how he \"crossed the flood,\" or \"crossed over attachment to the world.\"  The Buddha responds by saying that it is by not halting and not straining that he crossed the flood, and that when halting he sank, and when straining he was swept away.  The devatā then rejoices that he found a person who had crossed over & disappears.\n\nBodhi's notes on commentaries indicate that not halting & not straininig refer to the middle path, and the submerging of water is the bond to kāma or to conciousness & rebirth. \n\nMy interpretatation is that you can't sit idly by and ignore the senses to become emancipated, nor can you strive so much that inner composure is lost.  It is by mindfulness and clear comprehension coupled w/ non-clinging which helps you float in a flood.  This may or may not be in line with other suttas because striving and straining can be important (like in the vitakasanthana sutta - removing unwholesome thoughts)","tags":["flood","devā","straining","halting","middle way","sensuality","composure","laziness"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/sn1.1"],"_id":"SN:1.1","_rev":"10-07c6a4c7dab242bff350ebefaca84837","_revisions":{"start":10,"ids":["07c6a4c7dab242bff350ebefaca84837","04922af74368a838cd2932d74d5fe864","5387aad7e5b5d0454cb702a0b99118f9","b4858a322ef00e95ea093c53a7e7fd57","6dce8657f46728d9ebf7868d0180bf7d","ef03b7f15befb4435348f53112ea3052","4f4172be9bc9b507f417b9f98669dcf2","49758dfabbbc2dddfa31231e6a92d8a9","a233b1e942afb5811d54f90713a874b3","4de4999858793583baec3642b4c69ad8"]}},{"title":"Donapaka Sutta","summary":"The Buddha sees king Pasenadi panting and huffing trying to reach him after having eaten a bucket full of rice & curry.  The Buddha tells him that one should be mindful of when one is full, eating moderately.  This reduces ones troubles and extends ones lifespan.  As a consequence, the king ate only a cup/pint full of rice (a day?) and became slender with the constant reminder of his servant repeating the buddha's words.","tags":["food","pasenadi","diet"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn03/sn03.013.olen.html"],"_id":"SN:3.13","_rev":"6-97980aa99d48d037960afea62432d6e9","_revisions":{"start":6,"ids":["97980aa99d48d037960afea62432d6e9","539e97d62bc66667f709b65ba8dec803","928c363ed126a2d8cf9ecb4263306fac","79f1bf89987ebca09be9b30e31029016","dc8a7472e3b69b69d155f11df864bbe3","7af9ad955d4119c7c21bf3ba0d468e9d"]}},{"title":"Dh&#x12B;tu","summary":"King pasenadi has a daughter and laments not having a son. The Buddha tells him that a woman may turn out better than a man in virtuosity devotion, wisdom, as well as being able to bear a hero son, or one who rules \"the realm\"","tags":["Women","pasenadi","mallika"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/03-Kosala-Samyutta/02-Aputtakavaggo-e.html"],"_id":"SN:3.16","_rev":"3-4713445ec0d2a4247bbc865959562b08","_revisions":{"start":3,"ids":["4713445ec0d2a4247bbc865959562b08","4ec978fc427e4a19341ea5f6714137ff","f800e8a2fbfd4f55cae1bbe97dc18e37"]}},{"title":"Appam&#x101;da","summary":"","tags":["Diligence","persistence"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn03/sn03.017.than.html"],"_id":"SN:3.17","_rev":"2-2ad08ed8add1321d3faf7d5f75764a8e","_revisions":{"start":2,"ids":["2ad08ed8add1321d3faf7d5f75764a8e","0e451ee0681466c141ba5ead2d4a24f8"]}}]}

{"docs":[{"title":"Kaly&#x101;&#x1E47;amitta","summary":"This is the sutta where the Buddha tells King pasenadi his words to Ananda that good friendship is the whole of the Holy life. He explains that the person with good friends will develop each part of the noble eightfold path \"based upon seclusion dispassion, and cessation\". If you rely on the Buddha, you can be free of birth, aging death, sorry, lamentation, etc. Once you have good friends, diligence in wholesome states. This person attains the good in this life & the next","tags":["Friendship","Ananda"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/03-Kosala-Samyutta/02-Aputtakavaggo-e.html"],"_id":"SN:3.18","_rev":"5-96c45af6bd16b16c0fdd35027d140329","_revisions":{"start":5,"ids":["96c45af6bd16b16c0fdd35027d140329","ae942a0baccbdcf4d19a751b179237af","bb2bfbc6468e96787aa67e2ca83a1e3f","0d8b23e278f433086f8295b1bdaab57e","1344134c43e3184dead3e5d1b0e3cdcb"]}},{"title":"Aputtaka 1","summary":"The buddha asks king pasenadi why he's walking about in the middle of the day.  The king had just come from a wealthy, but miserly, man's house that was filled with riches.  The man ate very basic & little food, wore very little clothes and drove a basic cart. He died without a will, and this prompted the buddha to give a discourse on spending, not stockpiling money. The buddha recognizes that this is mara, affirms that such penances aimed at the  \"immortal state\" are useless and by virtue, concentration, and wisdom he has attained supreme purity. Māra leaves sad and disappointed that the buddha \"knows\" him. \n\nI wonder if Māra has the ability to put false doubts in someone's mind. He also says the bhikkhus are as well, and that they should wander forth for the welfare of the multitude, out of compassion for the world. They are to teach the dhamma good in the beginning, middle and end with right meaning and phrasing. \n\nThis passage really conveys that the realizations of the Arahants seem to be on par with the Buddha's, and that the bodhisattva ideal is actually rather limited in the sense that an Arahant will be able to actually produce understanding of dhamma in others, presumably leading them to nibbana.","tags":["Teaching","wandering","snares","compassion","Arahant"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/sn4.5"],"_id":"SN:4.5","_rev":"4-7f806a2ed7cdba20306d1c7359aff733","_revisions":{"start":4,"ids":["7f806a2ed7cdba20306d1c7359aff733","b4dc6ad96d94e79eb2891fc26e8875b3","0edaff744ede623c454f3ea095c0cfd8","7dcbc3fb4bb9ec55024d3e1c8c0725f9"]}},{"title":"Sappa - Serpent","summary":"The Buddha was approached by a a giant serpent, which was Mara in disguise. The Buddha declared that one should dwell in empty huts, self controlled, having relinquished all. In this way, staying there, even if there were many fearsome creatures, the sage remains calm - \"stirs not a hair\". Staying in an empty hut, \"the enlightened take no shelter in acquisitions\" while men try to kill \"their beast\" and other creatures stricken with terror at thunder and earthquakes.","tags":["Thunder","earthquakes","empty huts","relinquishment","serpent","Mara"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/sn4.6"],"_id":"SN:4.6","_rev":"4-1c948b62320186c24299e0d70223677d","_revisions":{"start":4,"ids":["1c948b62320186c24299e0d70223677d","b67b6f5d1e04fd82cd2e088434fec0d8","8f7ac26755ba1bb37feb4da6a0e64959","09264ff197298913833e7272d77ee179"]}}]}

{"docs":[{"title":"Satipatthana Sutta","summary":"","tags":["mindfulness","seven enlightenment factors","five hinderances","5 aggregates","6 sense bases","4 noble truths","phenomena","mind","feeling","body"],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"MN:10","_rev":"5-22be8ddedf8b103b91d98a1fd068ff6d","_revisions":{"start":5,"ids":["22be8ddedf8b103b91d98a1fd068ff6d","61bdbacefc7836fcb1b695575ed87aed","2baf42b9ce15bb15c60131e7ba2f4181","ca123f1bb6afd4e236e0ca7b91ef59d9","472a23bd80f019ab6980e0fd56e029ba"]}},{"title":"Cūlasīhanāda Sutta -  Shorter Discourse on the Lion's Roar","summary":"The Buddha proclaims that other doctrines are devoid of recluses (BB notes say these 4 recluses are the 4 noble types of people), and retelling this fact is \"rightly roar [ing] your lion's roar\".  When people of other doctrines ask by what authority do you say this, the 4 declarations of the buddha should be told after seeing them for oneself (confidence in the Teacher, confidence in the Dhamma, fulfillment of the precepts, companions in the Dhamma are dear and agreeable to us whether they be laymen or those gone forth. \n\nIf they then say they they observe these 4 things for their own teacher and tradition, a distinction is to be made.  That the goal is one, not many, is for one freed of lust, is for one freed of hate, freed from delusion, free from craving, free from clinging, with vision, for one who does not favor and does not oppose, for one that does not delight and enjoy proliferation.\n\nAny bhramins who don't understand gratification, danger and escape in the case of 2 views (view of being and the view of non-being) are affected by lust, hate, delusion, craving, clinging, without vision, given to favoring and opposing, delight in & enjoy proliferation.  They aren't freed from birth aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, despair, suffering. But any bhramin who understands the gratificaiton, danger, and escape in the the case of these 2 views are freed from all these things.\n\nThere are 4 kinds of clinging: to sensual pleasures, to views, to rules and observances, to a doctrine of self. There are brahmins that claim to expound all forms of clinging, but really they only talk about the clinging to sensual pleasures b/c they do not know the 3 other forms of clinging as they are. This can happen w/ someone who says that clinging is only to sensual pleasures and views, but not the other two, or to one who says the first 3 but not the clinging to doctrine of self.  The buddha says it is plain that confidence in their Teacher, Dhamma, fulfillment of their precepts, and affection among companions is not rightly directed.  This is because the Dhamma & discipline, when badly proclaimed is not emancipating, unconducive to peace, expounded by one who isn't fully enlightened.  But a Tathāgatha, fully enlightened, claims all these forms of clinging, then is the Dhamma rightly proclaimed. \n\nThese 4 kinds of clinging have craving as their source and origin. Craving has feeling as it's source. Feeling has contact, contact has the 6 sense bases, the senses have name and form, name and form has conciousness, conciousness has volitional formations, sankharas have ignorance as their source. When ignorance is abandoned & true knowledge arises, one no longer clings to sensual pleasures, views, rules & observances, to a doctrine of self. When he doesn't cling, he isn't agitated.  Not being agitated, he personally attains Nibbāna, understanding \"birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being\".","tags":["lion's roar","clinging","views","gratification danger escape","types of clinging","dependent origination","nibbāna"],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"_id":"MN:11","_rev":"5-a1b2f7243996de38a125a4c01116d9c7","_revisions":{"start":5,"ids":["a1b2f7243996de38a125a4c01116d9c7","21def3deac401446a44d45b344ae7cec","01cd359f6c94f43e33e0573a5fd75823","a6e43c57026d1c3f9ee29f543bee2441","aacf09df7df3b576572fab1af3239f90"]}},{"title":"P&#x101;s&#x101;&#x1E47;a","summary":"g","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/sn4.11"],"questions":"","notes":"note1","_id":"SN:4.11","_rev":"14-b44c89363c749eef71ce5b655b7a9ea3","_revisions":{"start":14,"ids":["b44c89363c749eef71ce5b655b7a9ea3","683889f43326f6277cd69315ced772fb","2f2e3c8f8d53821a4536795710cdd4ea","46680bd219d6106cbb25be0968f504ba","8b4995af08c97be7ef22be17708624fe","677eef644f852d4f800c57e2f8953bbc","db78aea6b59d9479b741e20cd3bd3870","1d4bd820a4b31d80217c9a847bea969c","4f9658598cfdffd2d57842a957e38b7c","4e9e10598da30f8e0058a15e30f1d693","d6cd34b16ef46059f2b58916592cb774","cf7c9940ef128f5a0d42cead4b502aec","18e349fa228dc77d4ba693b80b1a8425","b53915788e121c62dcbb02b93e8ddbe2"]}},{"title":"M&#x101;radh&#x12B;tu","summary":"This is the last sutta in the marā samyutta, in which mara's daughters try to sway the buddha where their father could not. The manifested as many forms, as women young, old, not having had children, having had children, etc. Eventually one of them asks how he dwells.  His response is this:\n\n\"Tranquil in body, in mind well liberated,\nNot generating, mindful, homeless, \nKnowing Dhamma, meditating thought-free,\nHe does not erupt, or drift, or stiffen.\"\n\nAnd he says when a bhikkhu often dwells  & meditates like this, sensual perceptions are kept at bay and do not grip him.","tags":["sensual perceptions","mara's daughters","thoughts","meditation","maidens","generating"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/sn4.25"],"questions":"Does meditating thought-free solely reference the jhānas or other types of meditation too?","notes":"This response of the buddha is quite profound to me.  \"Not generating\" might mean not producing kāmma. {"docs":[{"title":"Godhika","summary":"Venerable Godhika reached \"temporary liberation\" 6 times, and \"he fell away\" each time.  A 7th time, he reached this temporary liberation, but knowing he fell away 6 times before, he thought \"to use the knife\" (commit suicide).  Māra approached the blessed one, asking how this could possibly be, that a \"trainee seeking his mind's ideal\" would take his own life, and telling him that he should restrain Godhika. The buddha replies that the steadfast act as such, since they are not attached to life, having drawn out \"craving with its root\", and that Godhika has attained final Nibbāna.\n\nThe Buddha then takes his disciples up to see Godhika's body.  Once they arrive, Māra is searching and searching as a black cloud of smoke for Godhika's conciousness, but the buddha declares that his conciousness was \"unestablished\" having attained parinibbāna.\n\nMāra comically drops his lute from under his arm, disappointed, disappeared after the buddha tells him that Godhika attained final nibbāna.","tags":["temporary liberation","suicide","parinibbāna","godhika","knife","lute"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/sn4.23"],"questions":"Q) What specifically is meant by \"temporary liberation\"?","notes":"This sutta is extremely curious to me, not because of the suicide, but by the \"temporary liberation\".  One point could be that temporary liberation is not  nibbāna w/ remainder, but some other state such that, upon death leads to final nibbāna. Although I'm not so sure why the buddha would condone such an act (is proving a point of non-attachment to life worth it?).\n\nTalked to Steve, he suggested looking at the chinese translations and doing an online search for the phrase.  Apparently there are search engines that can search conjugations and declensions. Looking at the english translation of one of the chinese parallels, it's very much the same although it's expanded to say that Godhika was attained in all 4 jhanas and had temporary liberation from personality view (temporary sotapanna?).","_id":"SN:4.23","_rev":"12-e1ced14661b300ad56afff77c954dc96","_revisions":{"start":12,"ids":["e1ced14661b300ad56afff77c954dc96","ecf3998f30ba06111466745d8dc53aaa","5c1990545e2fc5d96ee86aa6bf950ebc","4ce8b5ce32202647616544c61d346573","31335243923c9274ed1290ff03b9324a","88b1b9ad6818910d8ac469dcf9ace7a7","e99d3a9b52cdb0dfbf089b38ac4ff3a1","adc517e93dd970a9cb1b04ffc4600305","87e6f9a08c8df92793bfddc60a9c43b9","d4dbcf4c0e0ba3bd23474b863fd725b6","eb5fbe452414f13579a131f718506453","dd797dd7412aa7ce98b6926f984d7f6c"]}},{"title":"Vajir&#x101","summary":"Vajira settles, like all the bhikkhunis nd is visited by Mara. He tries to throw her off by asking questions that assume a being is present. She asks is that your speculative view? She also proclaims that the world is burning, ablaze, quaking and that which does not blaze or quake has no place for mara. \nThis is where her mind delights.","tags":["delight","upacana","burning","quaking","heavens"],"parallels":[],"translations":["https://suttacentral.net/en/sn5.7"],"questions":"Her mind delights in nibbāna. His mind was \"inclined\" to not teach the dhamma since it is so refined and subtle (dependent origination & the state of stilling all formations, destruction of craving, dispassion). The current generation rejoices in \"adhesion\" and the dhamma is not easily understood by those oppressed by lust and hate, and he only found the dhamma after much hardship & going against the stream. Teaching uninstructable people would bring hardship upon himself. Then, brahma sahampati knowing the mind of the buddha pled with him to teach, telling him to look with his \"buddha's eye\" to see those that had little dust in their eyes.  Agreeing to this out of compassion, the buddha saw them and realized that the doors to the deathless are open to them. Unlike lotuses that grow underneath the water, that grow on top of the water, there are people who can see the dhamma like lotuses that flourish above the water. The buddha then says \"let those who have ears release faith\" implying that he will go out and teach.","tags":["dust in eyes","brahma sahampati","sahampati","hesitation","dependent origination","buddha's eye","lotus"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn06/sn06.001.than.html"],"questions":"","notes":"Unlike what I thought previously, the buddha doesn't really hesitate to teach, but rather glazes over those with little dust in their eyes. {"docs":[{"title":"G&#x101;rava","summary":"Another sutta about the buddha dwelling right after his enlightenment. He thinks that he should find a teacher to revere and honor b/c without reverence and deference, one \"dwells in suffering.\" But, he thinks that if he were to honor, respect and dwell in dependence on another ascetic or brahmin, he would be doing so out of an unfulfilled aggretate of virtue, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and knowledge and vision of liberation.  Yet, he does not see any other brahmin with any of these qualities more developed than himself, so he chooses to revere the dhamma instead. \n\nBrahma sahampati shows up, paying his respects, and affirms there is no one else that is more developed and that revering the dhamma instead is a natural law of the buddha as past buddhas have done it. Future buddhas will do it to.  \"desiring his own good... [one] should deeply rever the true Dhamma, recollecting the buddha's teachings.\"","tags":["perfection","budhahood","sahampati","reverence","Dhamma","more developed","development"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn06/sn06.002.than.html"],"questions":"","notes":"it's possible sahampati's role is a later addition, to authorize the buddha as an independent figurehead, but this addition would have to be pretty early. This sutta also occurs in the anguttara nikaya.","_id":"SN:6.2","_rev":"5-4e5df10bc86a0a02676fd8f91e5b8c50","_revisions":{"start":5,"ids":["4e5df10bc86a0a02676fd8f91e5b8c50","dc8a4a1493ead2e38e60f7db03032587","aefca498a42d6a039b0e24c4afba1a1e","b084674bf68a487d6d05fb22ec61a933","15a574ac58e701892f961911cabd2032"]}},{"title":"Brahmadeva","summary":"This sutta recounts a mother who always gives alms to Brahmā.  Her son, called brahmadeva, attains arahantship in full by dwelling alone, diligent, ardent, resolute.  In the morning after, brahmā sahampati visits brahmadeva's mother, telling her (\"standing in the air\") that the brahmā realm is far and doesn't eat human alms food, she should give to her  son instead.  She is told Brahmadeva deserves alms from humans and devas since he is so well developed and peaceful, untroubled by anything that comes his way. Brahma sahampati also says that he doesn't own anything.","tags":["brahmadeva","standing in the air","paccekabuddha","independent"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/06-Brahma-Samyutta/01-Kokalikavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"Did brahmadeva learn the dhamma from the buddha, or did he find it on his own?","notes":"A curious sutta that no mention of brahmadeva's relationship with the buddha. The Buddha then travels to the brahmā realm (as easily as a strong man might flex his arm) and tells him that it is not permanent and that Baka is deluding himself. Baka offers resistance, and asks why the buddha thinks his lifespan is only 100,000 nirabbudas.  The buddha recalls a past life where Baka was a great leader that did a lot of compassionate acts, and the buddha was his devout attendant. {"docs":[{"title":"Kok&#x101;lika 2","summary":"The bhikkhu kokalika proclaimed to the Buddha that Sariputta and mogallana have come \"under the control of evil wishes\". {"docs":[{"title":"Dhammadāyāya Sutta - Heirs in Dhamma","summary":"The Buddha begins by saying that the bhikkhus should be \"heirs in dhamma\" not in material things, because otherwise they'd both be reproachable. He then tells them that he would respect and commend a weak & hungry bhikkhu who refuses the buddha's alms scraps, contemplating living as an heir to dhamma weak & hungry over one who takes the scraps and is not weak and hungry. This is because this will \"conduce to his fewness of wishes, contentment, effacement, easy support, and arousal of energy.\"  Then Sariputta is asked if he could answer how disciples who live in seclusion do not train in seclusion.  For this, elder monks, middle monks, and new monks are blamed for 3 reasons: 1)they do not train in seclusion 2) they do not abandon what the buddha says to abandon 3) they are luxurious and careless, neglectful of seclusion. Those who do follow the right way of seclusion should be commended though. He says the evil that lies therein is greed & hate, anger & resentment, contempt and insolence, envy and avarice, deceit and fraud, obstinacy and rivalry, conceit and arrogance, vanity and negligence. The solution is the middle way/eightfold path.","tags":["middle way","eightfold path","heirs","food","seclusion","abandonment","alms"],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"questions":"","notes":"","_id":"MN:3","_rev":"7-e9ff6cee69763fe417c645f1ec5fadfa","_revisions":{"start":7,"ids":["e9ff6cee69763fe417c645f1ec5fadfa","e11e77392bd364b533e991460b5ef0e0","54136356bcc1495a683ed7f502e1e349","1489c7d5c984ced785bb2930fdc7fb88","4b1c542d06795ec39b16fc8a685481ee","ac49d4ea4e408cedc7d6e9a0f7c7819a","a6cbb9a2121ba0491d97d16c26fbfa3e"]}},{"title":"Aru&#x1E47;avat&#x12B;","summary":"the buddha recounts a time of a past buddha named Sikhī, who had 2 chief disciples abhibhū and sambhava. Sikhī buddha decided to go to the heavens to have abhibhū give a teaching to brahmā and all the deities there. The brahmas enjoyed the first teaching, but they thought it was a little inappropriate that it wasn't the buddha who gave it.  Sikhiī told his disciple to give another teaching, but project his voice across the \"thousand fold world system\".  He talked about striving for the attainment of the deathless, and keeping energy aroused. The brahmās accepted this one with no problem, and after returning to the human realm, sikhī asked his other disciples if they heard abhibhū, and they confirmed so.","tags":["sikhī","past buddha","energy","striving","persistence","brahmā realm","devas"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/06-Brahma-Samyutta/02-Parinibbanavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"this sutta is about a past buddha, which isn't something that is done often in the suttas.","_id":"SN:6.14","_rev":"4-545cd6ae8261b66ffcb771664be26c4b","_revisions":{"start":4,"ids":["545cd6ae8261b66ffcb771664be26c4b","0445a7ef8ab2ce242f2d206114fea032","21a2a8c3e2b79e132c168909d6ac47e9","1a4716d246864c890db131ee6f6cf1ca"]}},{"title":"Parinibb&#x101;na","summary":"This sutta outlines the buddha's parinibbana. His final words were \"now i address you bhikkhus: formations are bound to vanish. strive to attain the goal by diligence.\" \nAfter saying this, he entered the first, 2nd 3rd, 4th jhanas, then the base of infinity of space, base of infinity of consiousness, base of nothingness, base of neither percepiton nor non perception, then finally the cessation of perception and feeling. Then, he descened back down all the way to 1st jhana, and ascended to 4th, finally being liberated wholly and completely.  Brahma sahampati, Sakka, ananda, and anuruddha all recited verses extolling the buddha and his teaching (except ananada's which is about how fear and trepidation arising after the parinibbana).","tags":["parinibbana","sakka","brahma sahampati","anuruddha","ananda","jhana","immaterial attainments","diligence","striving","right effort","right concentration"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn06/sn06.015.than.html"],"questions":"does the wording \"emerged\" indicate jhanas/bases as separate attainments rather than them flowing into one another?","notes":"Only Ananda's verse was not about the buddha & his qualities. Her husband heard this and called her wretched and took off to refute the Buddha's doctrine. Once he gets there though, he only asks what one thing the Buddha approves of killing. {"docs":[{"title":"Akkosa","summary":"An angry abusive brahmin approaches the Buddha and abused him with rude and harsh words. The Buddha then eloquently explains that his anger is like a rejected food offering, still only belonging to the brahmin. The brahmin replied that the Buddha is angry when he says this, but the Buddha affirms that he lives in peace, and that paying someone with anger makes things worse for himself. Rather you should practice for the welfare of both and mindfully maintain peace. Then a stock phrase declaring Akkosaka's faith and going forth and eventual enlightenment.","tags":["Anger","abuse","verbal abuse","peace"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn07/sn07.002.budd.html"],"questions":"","notes":"This is a very inspiring sutta on verbal abuse. Aggika affirms, and offers him his own food, given to him to perform a fire sacrifice. The buddha rejects this offer since it was given out of a desire to perform a sacrifice, and is thus unfit for consumption. {"docs":[{"title":"Bahudh&#x12B;tu","summary":"A brahmin, whose lost 14 oxen in the woods, goes searching for them and finds the buddha.  He sees the buddha sitting \"with his legs folded crosswise, holding his body erect, having set up mindfulness in front of him.\" The brahmin asks the buddha oddly specific questions such as if he has 14 lost oxen to give him trouble, a field of blighted seasamum plants some with one leaf some with two, rats in an empty barn, ...7 daughters left as widows, etc. \n\nThese questions presumably reflect aspects of the bhramin's life with which he is unhappy.  Of course the buddha answers in the negative to all of his questions, affirming that he has a lot of happiness because of the lack of duties/possessions.\n\nThen the end is the stock phrase \"Magnificent...magnificent...became enlightened\"","tags":["possessions","renunciation","happiness","peace","mindfulness","duties"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/07-Brahmana-Samyutta/01-Arahantavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"BB translates the buddha's mindfulness as being setup \"in front of him.\" - The buddha replies that he does plough, perplexing kasi.  The buddha explains that \"faith is the seed, austerity the rain, wisdom my yoke and plough, shame is the pole, mind the yoke tie, and mindfulness my ploughshare and goad.\"  He also says he uses energy to carry him to where one does not sorrow, finally proclaiming that after all this work \"ploughing\" the fruit is the deathless and release from all suffering.","tags":["sutta nipata","ploughing","austerity","wisdom","shame","nibbāna"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn07/sn07.011.than.html"],"questions":"","notes":"There is a parallel in the sutta nipata (76-82 on the Laurence Mills SC version) with the exact name of the brahmin and nearly exact same content, except the sutta nipāta version, the buddha rejects a meal that was given to the brahmin for chants","_id":"SN:7.11","_rev":"7-4bca6afb7f5c88baaba13c1e7937736a","_revisions":{"start":7,"ids":["4bca6afb7f5c88baaba13c1e7937736a","ce62c802e4b0093599c74da2ec487d1e","8165fab292de0658de39be02339e49fd","a86cb857fd06bbd6b233217a6b600eb4","06b82454d732ed52f61426bb4177c1db","2f9357fb5df290ecd5e3feb8b91e52fc","dbccc3515f1b70e2c1c61dafda0e96e8"]}},{"title":"Udaya","summary":"udaya complains that the buddha keeps coming for alms again and again.  The buddha says that, again and again \"they sow the seed...the sky god sends down rain...plough the field... grain comes...[the life cycle of a cow & dairy production...one is born and dies...take[n] to the cemetary.\"  But one who has obtained the path is not born again and again.","tags":["rebirth","alms"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn07/sn07.012.olen.html"],"questions":"","notes":"","_id":"SN:7.12","_rev":"3-cc4dc57583509e3d05e3cfe24234a589","_revisions":{"start":3,"ids":["cc4dc57583509e3d05e3cfe24234a589","46e84b9c1b142622dda2ef0c88f84e15","8fb0fdaa71eea49fd4eb77001a1d2770"]}},{"title":"Sundarika","summary":"A brahmin, wishing to share his fire sacrifice food offering with a worthy one, goes to the seated buddha and upon seeing his shaved head, doesn't think he's worthy. He remembers that some brahmins have shaved heads though, and asks him about his birth. \n\nthe buddha tells him not to ask about birth, but by conduct as a person of low birth who is a \"sage\"  and restrained by a sense of shame is worthy.  The brahmin sundarika then offers the sacrificial cake to the buddha, who refuses it on account of the ritual.  Sundarika then asks who else would be worthy, but the buddha's reply is that he sees no one else other than himself and disciples who are worthy, but will only eat it out of generosity and sustenance, thereafter directing the brahmin to throw it away.\n\nThe brahmin threw it away in water that didn't contain animals, and it sizzled and smoked. He came back to the buddha, terrified.  The buddha said that kindling wood (fire sacrfice?) does not bring purity, nor do external gestures, but inner work instead.","tags":["brahmanism","fire sacrifice","sizzled","alms","birth","caste","food waste"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/07-Brahmana-Samyutta/01-Arahantavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"The buddha says his mind is always concentrated, always ablaze.\n\nIn reference to the fire sacrifice, conceit is the shoulder-load, anger is the smoke, false speech the ashes, tounge is teh ladle, heart teh altar, \"well tamed self\" is the light of a man.  The dhamma is a lake with fords of virtue, limipd, praised by the good, and dry limbed, cross to the far shore.\n\nHe also mentions \"attainment of Brahmā based on the middle\".  It's not explicit that he's referring to arahants, but it's implied.  This is quite an unusual phrasing, as the buddha again appeals to the brahmin's sensibilities/framework even though he originally denied authority to \"shavelings.\"","_id":"SN:7.9","_rev":"4-f99592dd7125939a76ca95d01ee7e988","_revisions":{"start":4,"ids":["f99592dd7125939a76ca95d01ee7e988","1a10e2d93fc2c37787a398e720ece509","5a39bdc5175015f5026dd18a3ae45add","41d9fb8ebe4e19db59f886b540533c53"]}}]}

{"docs":[{"title":"Mahāsīhanāda Sutta - The Greater Discourse on the Lion's Roar","summary":"Sunakkhatta tries disparaging the blessed one by saying that he has no supernormal powers, his ideas are mere reasoning, but also says his teachings lead to the complete destruction of suffering.  The buddha tells sariputta that, though he tries an insult, he is actually complimenting him, and he will never infer that the buddha is accomplished, fully enlightened...that the blessed one enjoys the various kinds of supernormal power (duplication of self, unification after duplication, appearing & vanishing, walking through solid objects, diving in & out of the earth as though through water, levitation/movement through space cross-legged, and touching the sun & moon, hearing the heavenly and human sounds with the divine ear, reading minds - the 7 states of mind + greed, hatred, delusional minds).\n\nHe then tells sariputta that he possesses 10 powers of a tathāgata, which when claimed is his lion's roar, setting the motion of the wheel of brahmā. These are, understanding what is truly possible/impossible, understanding the results of actions undertaken (past present and future) by way of possibilities and causes, understanding the ways leading to all destinations, and the reality of the world with its many and different elements, and beings different inclinations, dispositions of the faculties of other beings, defilement/cleaning and emergence in regard to jhānas liberations concentrations and attainments,  seeing his own past lives, with divine eye sees disappearing and reappearing of inferior/superior fair/ugly... of beings according to their actions, abiding in taintless deliverance of mind and wisdom.\n\nHe then tells sariputta that he has 4 kinds of intrepidity. 1) abiding in the seeing that there is no grounds for saying he isn't fully enlightened 2) and not having destroyed the taints 3) and speaking falsely about obstructions 4) and that his teachings do not lead to end of suffering.\n\n8 assemblies: of nobles, of brahmins, householders, recluses, gods of the heaven of the 4 great kings, gods of the heaven of the 33, māra's retinue, and of brāhmas. In all of these assemblies, the buddha says he was neither timid nor fearful because there is no ground for that.\n\n4 kinds of generation: born of an egg, born of womb, born of moisture, spontaneous generation. egg birth is the breaking out of a hard egg, womb is exactly what it sounds like, moisture is born in a rotten fish corpse porridge cesspit or sewer.  spontaneous is gods, residents of hell and certain humans in these realms.\n\n5 destinations and nibbāna. Hell, animal realm, realm of ghosts, humans, gods.  The buddha says he understands all of these, the way leading to them, and the results of the path leading to them. He also understands nibbāna and how the result of entering the path is an abiding in the deliverance of mind by wisdom with the destruction of the taints.\n\nHe then elaborates these states, having perceived them with the divine eye that \"surpasses the human\" if its the hell realm, or encompassing \"mind with mind\" for the others. Hell is experiencing exclusively painful feelings, like someone, parched and wearied, who is on the path to a very deep pit filled with scorching hot coals, falls in that pit because of the actions he has taken.  The animal realm is experiencing painful racking feelings, like the simile above but with a pit of filth. The realm of ghosts has much painful feeling, like a man weary and parched coming to a tree on uneven ground with little and uneven shade. The realm of humans is experiencing much pleasant feeling, like the tree above but with deep shade offering much pleasant feelings. The realm of happy destination is in heavenly world, exclusively pleasant feelings like a well secured and well furnished mansion. Nibbāna is the result of a path that realizes direct knowledge, and experiences exclusively pleasant feelings. Like a pond with clean agreeable cool water, transparent with smooth banks, delightful, with a nearby dense wood after having bathed and drunk relieves all distress, fatigue and fever. \n\nThe bodhisatta's austerities\nhis holy life possessed 4 factors: being an ascetic, being coarse, being scrupulous, and secluded, all being done to the \"supreme\".\nHis asceticism was rejecting conventions, licking his hands, not coming when asked, not stopping when asked, not accepting food brought or specially made or and invitation to a meal. received nothing from a pot, bowl, across a threshold, across a stick, pestle, from 2 eating together, from a pregnant woman...etc tormenting and mortifying the body. His coarseness was that he wouldn't bath and dust/dirt would flake off his skin. His scrupulousness was being mindful of stepping forward and back, full of pity by not letting even a drop of water touch the ground for fear of hurting the animals in the cracks. His seclusion was in a forest, fleeing from people. \nHe also said he fed on filth: the dung of calves, his own dung and urine. Expose himself to the elements, sleep in a charnel ground, on the bones of the dead as a pillow, abiding in equanimity as boys spat on him, threw dirt, poked sticks in his ears, being equanimous the entire time without a mind of evil. \n\nHe says that there are people who try purifying themselves on kola fruit, so he at one a day and became extremely emaciated, offering a lot of detail into these distorted physical features. The same goes for those sects eating only beans, seasamum, rice, he tried them all. Yet despite all of this he did not gain any wisdom which would lead to superhuman states and distinction of  knowledge. \nthere are also recluses that purification comes after rounds of rebirth in all the realms, yet the buddha said it isn't easy to find a realm he hadn't already been through, except through the realm of the gods of the pure abodes, which if he had been to he would never return as a human being (according to bb notes, this is only possible for non-returners). \nThere are brahmins that say purification comes through [sacrifice, fire worship], but he said it would be difficult to find a sacrifice he didn't make. \nThere's also the idea that only young, black haired people have lucid wisdom, yet he says he is 80 in this sutta, and possesses full lucidity of wisdom, such that he could talk for 100 years on mindfulness and still not exhaust his explanations.\n\"were it to be said of anyone 'a being not subject to delusion...for the happiness of many, out of compassion for the world, for the good, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans' it is of me ...this should be said\".\n\nNāgasamāla exalts the buddha for this discourse, saying the hairs on his body stood up, and asks its name.  The buddha says it is \"The hair rising discourse\"","tags":["austerities","bodhisatta","supernatural power","reading minds","bed of nails"],"parallels":[],"translations":[],"questions":"","notes":"This is quite a sutta with a lot of lists, explaining the buddha's powers and austerities mostly.\n\nIf you're born in the realm of the pure abodes, you won't be reborn as a human again, according to this sutta.  I wonder if this has any connection to the origin of pure land buddhism.","_id":"MN:12","_rev":"7-4eed35664821f14b04e82cc9c9dd1aa6","_revisions":{"start":7,"ids":["4eed35664821f14b04e82cc9c9dd1aa6","001ef641cc96f839596603458d012c34","0d50b67251a3867b0aed3d8d19a015a3","a2755f8cc770ca8b909131be1fc74cf7","b8a624403578b06a9fe0c853b6be1ba9","64574b5c6912d2504d54bf19d6bd489c","4b5fda20ee11a71a4d8dfd1177e24b8c"]}},{"title":"Devahita","summary":"The buddha's attendant (Upavāna - before Ānanda?) goes to Devahita for alms of hot water to help with the buddha's illness - affliction of winds. He says he wishes to bring it to the buddha himself since the buddha is so renown.  Devahita had the buddha bathed in hot water and gave a mixing of water  +molasses as alms, leading to the subsiding of his ailments.  Devahita then asked how one should give alms so they are a proper gift, bear great fruit and the buddha says that they should be given to an arahant.","tags":["direct knowledge","alms","hot water","molasses"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/07-Brahmana-Samyutta/02-Upasakavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"an arahant is one who knows his past abodes, sees heaven and plane of woe, who has reached the descutions of birth and is \"consummate in direct knowledge\"","_id":"SN:7.13","_rev":"5-92bd4f4add9756fb666b55a5890c2238","_revisions":{"start":5,"ids":["92bd4f4add9756fb666b55a5890c2238","0443b71dbd1cf4079359b01b010afd5e","c3ec2028556f2bcdddff750c4f61d9bd","79c0cb4f6a37f1e8c69c1d0374ac3d9f","2bf8c3f7083a893cc1ceffe16a69382f"]}},{"title":"Mah&#x101;s&#x101;&#x1E37;a","summary":"An affluent brahmin is kicked out of his house by his sons, instigated by their wives (no other details provided). Conceited, he waits to be acknowledged by the buddha first.  Of course the buddha pays him no mind, and when he is about to turn away, dismissing the buddha as a unknowledgeable ascetic, the buddha reads his mind and tells him he is conceited.  \"For one keen on his welfare, berahmin, you should instead foster the purpose...of which you've come here.\"  The brahmin is dazzled by the fact that the buddha could read his mind, and prostrates himself right then and there, much to the surprise of those around him.  Mānatthaddha then asks the buddha to whom should one avoid conceit, show reverence, be respectful, and venerate deeply.  The buddha replies that firstly, it's your parents, then your oldest brother, then your teacher.  Then, having struck down conceit, humble, one should pay homage to the unsurpassed arahants.","tags":["respect","veneration","parents","mother","father","family","conceit","mind reading"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/07-Brahmana-Samyutta/02-Upasakavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"","_id":"SN:7.15","_rev":"7-352fcdda04171b433e666e36ee295856","_revisions":{"start":7,"ids":["352fcdda04171b433e666e36ee295856","9e0c28435d1339708a01789a57287554","d12d5a310ca0f7ca382388012063a2d0","883cd3872baa8b8b248d96f22c130792","4262889abbe51291ec1bd035a871a5c2","cf52603e386dc169f1b0de5e468d8434","7c1ee9d2257f6418296fa3c8dd6a8fa4"]}},{"title":"Paccan&#x12B;ka","summary":"","tags":["contradiction","understanding"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/07-Brahmana-Samyutta/02-Upasakavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"","_id":"SN:7.16","_rev":"2-75a14a8d323fe853ede24c66b2d43b14","_revisions":{"start":2,"ids":["75a14a8d323fe853ede24c66b2d43b14","4fd10cf211eded976445ae340917a00b"]}},{"title":"Navakammika","summary":"navakammika saw the buddha meditating and asks him what he takes delight in in the woods. Ananda asks him to go meet the brahmin at his house, and the buddha consents silently. The buddha, after greetings, asks him what benefit his water practice brings. The brahmin says it washes away his evil deeds, and the buddha makes a metaphor for the dhamma as a lake, with fords of virtue, where knowledgable masters go to bathe.","tags":["water","water purification","metaphor"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn07/sn07.021.wlsh.html"],"questions":"","notes":"","_id":"SN:7.21","_rev":"3-f7c4199cc6f90644637c7fb2e5760059","_revisions":{"start":3,"ids":["f7c4199cc6f90644637c7fb2e5760059","6ea01423581274e738cbe46c234f80e0","ffbc0b340fefe6436fd7ca9ac109a824"]}},{"title":"Khomadussa","summary":"The buddha goes for alms while the brahmins of the village were holding a council on some business matter while it was raining. Instead of giving in, he stands firm and recites a couple of verses that reinforce his determinations for the dhamma.  He says his mind finds delight in the path and \"the dark one\" can't even see this path.","tags":["mara","the dark one","newly ordained","new monk","temptation","lust"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/08-Vangisa-Thera-Samyutta/01-Vangisavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"this is an inspiring sutta about the trials a newly ordained monk goes through. Though he is bluntly resolute, his words are inspiring still","_id":"SN:8.1","_rev":"5-4054cb59f78595280f63ad0470d2f9ca","_revisions":{"start":5,"ids":["4054cb59f78595280f63ad0470d2f9ca","e4716896e9f8b4e55782cff2c0cca813","d96280b43cde13da551a3ff0e85d7cb1","c55462c7a0174e1c3ae86a91730f1e3e","982712c421d3bc7c2a7412b57ae850d4"]}},{"title":"Arati - Discontent","summary":"Vangisa again, feels dissatisfaction in the fact that his preceptor doesn't come around very often and stays secluded.  He arouses delight in himself and recites verses on abandoning discontent, delight, lust, as well as knowing that everything is impermentant, attachment breeds suffering, and concentration as the path to nibbana.","tags":["delight","vangisa","discontent","dissatisfaction"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/08-Vangisa-Thera-Samyutta/01-Vangisavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"Here is another place delight is seen in a negative way. {"docs":[{"title":"Pesal&#x101;tima&#xF1;&#xF1;an&#x101;","summary":"Vangisa realizes that he is looking down upon other monks practicing rightly.  Realizing this conceit, he recites verses to abandon it, saying those with that conceit are reborn in hell and those that practice the right path do not have conceit and are peaceful","tags":["conceit"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/08-Vangisa-Thera-Samyutta/01-Vangisavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"","_id":"SN:8.3","_rev":"3-cba4620a1149f1287cc3abd435acf2cf","_revisions":{"start":3,"ids":["cba4620a1149f1287cc3abd435acf2cf","e909aa471291c86e5283c8a78c1635c1","a47a9eb3c138d64938cfe17a292e5870"]}},{"title":"&#x100;nanda","summary":"Vangisa goes for alms with Ananda, and he says to him that his mind is engulfed by lust. Ananda tells him to \"turn away from the sign of beauty\" and to see all forms as alien, suffering, & not self.  He also tells him to become one pointed in foulness, keep mindfulness on the body, and be engrossed in revulsion. The final piece of advice is to develop meditation on the signless, to discard the tendency to conceit in order to be one \"who fares at peace\".","tags":["revulsion","repulsion","signless","engrossed","beauty","suffering","not self"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn08/sn08.004.than.html"],"questions":"","notes":"","_id":"SN:8.4","_rev":"3-921fbe0af84058d5e582a885d0316944","_revisions":{"start":3,"ids":["921fbe0af84058d5e582a885d0316944","d660d9db8ce3795ac3de5c74164a4def","e8dcedd031d0e6981a0b206e76fc78ed"]}},{"title":"Subh&#x101;sita","summary":"The buddha addresses bhikkhus with a definition of speech that is well spoken, blameless by the wise and which has 4 factors.  Only that which is well spoken, that which is dhamma, that which is pleasant, that which is true, and none of the opposites. He tells them the order determines importance of the factors, and then Vangisa says he has an inspiration and gains permission from teh buddha to say it. His inspiration is an explanation of those 4 factors, specifically saying well spoken speech is that which doesn't afflict you or ohters, and the others are obvious.","tags":["right speech","speech"],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/08-Vangisa-Thera-Samyutta/01-Vangisavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"","_id":"SN:8.5","_rev":"3-71f9ef0540c046d2547572f627efc9e1","_revisions":{"start":3,"ids":["71f9ef0540c046d2547572f627efc9e1","086bf2bdd0dcda6dc4eaa6571a498e4f","5801721d9bd35ae80af65a53ed499677"]}},{"title":"Pav&#x101;ra&#x1E47;&#x101;","summary":"","tags":[],"parallels":[],"translations":["http://awake.kiev.ua/dhamma/tipitaka/2Sutta-Pitaka/3Samyutta-Nikaya/Samyutta1/08-Vangisa-Thera-Samyutta/01-Vangisavaggo-e.html"],"questions":"","notes":"This sutta says that only 60 Arahants out of 500 have the triple knowledges (knowledge of one's own past life, past lives of others, and knowledge of the destruction of the taints).
